content.intro:
Fashion, design, architecture the Lombard capital cultivates beauty in all things and all forms.

Unlike her sister cities, Milan does not live in the past. Milan has been Roman, Lombard, French, Spanish, and Austrian, making it the most European of the Italian cities, and the most open to the future. Is it because it is the backbone of the Italian economy, its financial centre, the seat of the stock market? In Milan, churches sit next to skyscrapers, museums next to design showrooms, and an aria from La Scala may follow a soundtrack from a fashion show.
Milan is organised in a spiral. In the centre there is the Duomo, La Scala, and the Fashion Quadrangle. Here, in the cafés and boutiques, is where you breathe in the Milanese elegance and savoir-faire Stendhal loved so much. You can taste it in the panettone and the delicious Christmas cakes in the pastry shops. And, as you move away from the centre and closer to Brera and Porto Nuova, you discover a city that is aesthetic, creative, experimental, and environmental. Which would probably not displease one of the city's most cherished citizens, Leonardo da Vinci, if he were somehow alive today.
This is also where one finds Michelin-starred gastronomic cooking: Lombard cuisine boasts a young generation of chefs who are reinventing their native cuisine while remaining faithful to its roots. Is that not the ultimate proof of chic and elegance?

content.title: Cittamani, elegant and modern Indian cuisine

introduction.small: Indian chef Ritu Dalmia set up home in Milan's chic Brera district, reinventing the cuisine of her childhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cittamani, elegant and modern Indian cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Far from the busy and folkloric decoration of many traditional Indian restaurants, Cittamani has positioned itself on wavelength shared by its neighbourhood: chic, refined and keen on contemporary design. It is run by Ritu Dalmia, a great star of gastronomy in India. After the successful launch of a restaurant chain in her native country, the chef has now endeavoured to conquer Italy, with Milan as a starting point.

Ritu Dalmia reveals an Indian cuisine as rich as its décor, cooked with the extensive use of Lombard products, and she steers clear of curry-based dishes as much as possible, as she is not fond of the spice. Must-try naans are presented with a twist: pork confit, pumpkin or sweet potato. The tandoori gets rid of the traditional chicken in favour of roasted cauliflowers, and the masala spices up octopus, served with carrots in fenugreek and grilled lemon. This blast of flavours gives Cittamani its identity: the name derives from Sanskrit, evoking a tantric link at once sensual and emotional, mankind and nature being united during the tasting of a dish.

Cittamani
Piazza Carlo Mirabello 5
20121 Milano

+39 02 3824 0935

https://www.cittamani.com/en/

Menu: around 39 EUR

content.title: 28 Posti, laboratory of culinary experiences

introduction.small: Only a few steps away from Milan's canals, Marco Ambrosino successfully strings together a series of gastronomic experiences in his bistro-looking restaurant, 28 Posti.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 28 Posti, laboratory of culinary experiences

paragraphs.text:
In Milan, restaurant 28 Posti offers 28 seats – thus its name. However, comes sunshine and terrace seating blows that number high. The small number of rustic wooden tables juxtaposed with exposed and unadorned walls gives this bistro a somewhat confidential side. From the picture windows, you can catch a glimpse of Marco Ambrosino working his magic in the open kitchen. Far from traditional Italian gastronomy one may have in mind due to the slightly classical feel of the place, the creativity of the young chef borders on chemistry: smoky dishes, seaweed, fermented foods… One-of-a-kind ingredients always strike his curiosity and rapidly become staples for his experiences. Always looking for a challenge, Marco Ambrosino knows no rest and keeps food lovers surprised. The five, eight or ten-course menus change every two months, unveiling strange combinations that may seem odd on paper but undoubtedly win all contests when you try them… Booking is more than recommended, for this culinary laboratory is a major sell-out.

28 Posti
Via Corsico 1
20144 Milano

+39 02 839 2377

https://www.28posti.org

Menu: around 56 EUR

content.title: Surprising vegetarian gastronomy at MAM

introduction.small: In Milan's Porta Romana's neighbourhood, MAM looks like an old bistro but offers a modern cuisine using only organic and vegetarian ingredients.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Surprising vegetarian gastronomy at MAM

paragraphs.text:
1960s music can be heard coming out of the building. From the outside, the sounds are in perfect synch with the look of the establishment. Ancient china laid out on the shelves and chic retro furniture come straight from local second-hand goods dealers. At MAM – for Milano Amore Mio (“Milan, my love”) –, multiple references to the past can be spotted in the dining area, from the old solid wood counter to the drawings on the walls.
Conversely, the contents of your plate will reveal a most contemporary take on gastronomy, based on organic products. There, you cannot order, as the menu is a surprise. Once in your chair, just wait for the chef's daily special to ravish you. There is one thing for certain, all dishes are vegetarian-friendly: you may try a potato and pesto mille-feuille or a pumpkin custard in gorgonzola and paprika cream for instance. Take a break from everyday routines and let the surprise begin!

MAM
Via Lodovico Muratori 7
20135 Milan

+39 339 527 5306

www.facebook.com/MAM-Milano-Amore-Mio-1923147944577395/ ﻿

Menu: around 20 EUR

content.title: Dry pairs high-end pizzas and cocktails

introduction.small: Two steps away from the Republic Square in Milan, Dry's concept blends a hip bar with a trendy pizzeria.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dry pairs high-end pizzas and cocktails

paragraphs.text:
Pizza or cocktail tonight? In Milan, it is possible to combine the two! In the fashionable Porta Venezia neighbourhood, Dry is hiding in an historical building. Inside, the industrial style and contemporary minimalist decoration are in stark contrast with the bourgeois facade. On the ceilings, light bulbs attached to a metallic structure reveal an intimate atmosphere. As for its name, it derives from a reference to the American Prohibition when throats where "drying out".
The aperitivo being a national tradition, various addresses nearby offer drinks and antipasti combos. However, Dry's concept stands out with a bet on sheer quality: professional mixologists will prepare your drink - to be enjoyed in moderation - as the chef takes good care of your meal in the kitchen. Order a Life (gin-based cocktail with Tonka and banana liquors, lemon, almond syrup and egg white) or a Walk (whisky, agave, lime, rosemary herbal tea in the style of Japanese plum liquor, vermouth) to pair with a signature pizza. This pizza-cocktail mix is being so popular in Milan that it inspires others.

Dry Milano
Viale Vittorio Veneto 28
20124 Milano

+39 02 6347 1564

drymilano.it/#veneto

Menu: pizza from 5 EUR, cocktail from 12 EUR

content.title: The Pinacoteca di Brera, meeting with masters

introduction.small: In the heart of Milan, the paintings of the greats are available for the eyes of the curious.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pinacoteca di Brera, meeting with masters

paragraphs.text:
The Ancient and Modern art collection of the Pinacoteca di Brera is considered one of the most important in Italy. Housed in an old Baroque palace, it was the Academy of Fine Arts before hosting the pictorial works of great Italian masters of various art movements: Raphael, Caravaggio, Bellini, Botticelli and Modigliani are all here.

Behind its austere facade, the building offers an impressive succession of paintings that you will discover in chronological order according to their school. Giovanni Bellini's Pietà is next to Raphael's Wedding of the Virgin and Lamentation on the Dead Christ of Mantegna.

Before you enter, take a break in the inner courtyard in front of the bronze statue of the Roman god Mars, represented by Antonio Canova with the traits of Napoleon Bonaparte (who was at the origins of the museum's creation), then admire the magnificent corridors of pristine white.

Pinacoteca di Brera
Via Brera 28
20121 Milano

+39 02 7226 3230

https://pinacotecabrera.org

content.title: The Monumental Cemetery of Milan

introduction.small: Visit the Monumental Cemetery of the Lombard city, one of the largest and most beautiful in Europe, where each tomb is a work of art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Monumental Cemetery of Milan

paragraphs.text:
Far from being a traditional cemetery, this open-air museum presents a real 'gallery' of sculptures, each as impressive as the next, created between the 19th century and today, to pay homage to the dearly departed-authors, composers, architects, painters, men of the Church or actors, most of whom were from well-off families. The departed lie in astonishing decors, some of which are immense, as with the tomb of the last descendant of Mozart.

An oasis of peace and hideout for locals in search of tranquillity, the Monumental Cemetery conceals various touches of Roman and Gothic arts along its alleyways. You can admire a white-marble and red-stone tomb, enriched by Byzantine mosaic, torsade columns and a blue cupola and a sculpted replica of Leonardo da Vinci's The Last Supper on a tower ten metres high, where the life of Jesus is represented…

Piazzale Cimitero Monumentale
20154 Milano

+39 02 8846 5600

https://www.yesmilano.it/en/see-and-do/venues/monumental-cemetery

content.title: Dry Cocktails & Pizza: when Happy Hour comes

introduction.small: In the heart of Brera, the perfect place to share a pizza and try the oldest cocktail in Italy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dry Cocktails & Pizza: when Happy Hour comes

paragraphs.text:
Aperitifs, chatting, and snacking... no Milanese worthy of the name foregoes having a glass of something to end the day and start the evening. The best place to do this is at Dry. In the heart of Brera, this neo-industrial design bar is both pizzeria and cocktail bar. This is a place you get to late and stay at late. Choose a sofa with a view of the street, order a pizza or focaccia to share, and a select a cocktail, preferably the Milano Turino.

The Milano Turino was created in Milan in 1860; Dry's bartender, Guglielmo Miriello, has recently resurrected it. The original recipe is made of one-half Milan Campari, and the other half Turin Cinzano. Here, Miriello combines Campari and Vermouth, which is the pride of all Milan.

Dry Cocktails & Pizza
Via solferino 33
20 121 Milan

+ 39 (0)2 6379 3414

www.drymilano.it

Menu: around 12 EUR a pizza, 10 EUR a cocktail

content.title: Fondazione Prada: Muccia Prada's masterpiece

introduction.small: An original exhibition space set up in a former distillery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fondazione Prada: Muccia Prada's masterpiece

paragraphs.text:
Although a little eccentric, it is well worth visiting the Fondazione Prada. Designer Muccia Prada and her entrepreneur husband, Patrizio Bertelli, opened this 19,000-square-metre foundation in a former distillery. Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas redesigned the existing buildings and completed the other spaces, creating a labyrinth in which you can happily lose yourself.

Go up, go down, go from a small room to a large plateau wherever you are, the art is always stimulating. The foundation brings together classic and contemporary works in all disciplines, including film.

Above all, do not miss the room with the gilded tower called the 'haunted house', which is dedicated to Louise Bourgeois. The coffee bar, La Luce, is a great place to take a break from all the art; Muccia Prada persuaded filmmaker Wes Anderson to design it. Fusing formica and colour with a vintage Milanese café aesthetic, it is a true movie set!

Prada Foundation
Largo Isarco 2
20139 Milano

+39 02 5666 2611

www.fondazioneprada.org

content.title: La Scala: what a scene!

introduction.small: "Norma", "Otello", "Aida"... the walls of the world's most famous opera house have vibrated with the most beautiful of Italian operas. Thank you to Bellini, Rossini, Verdi…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Scala: what a scene!

paragraphs.text:
After the February 25th, 1776 fire, the Teatro Regio Ducale (Royal Ducal Theatre) was completely destroyed and Milan remained without an opera house for months. At the request of Maria Theresa of Austria, Queen of France, architect Giuseppe Piermarini was tasked with building a new one, this time where once stood the church of Santa Maria della Scala whose name Maria Theresa took. Construction was completed in 1778, after a mere two years.

Since then, La Scala has become synonymous with Italian opera. It is the most famous of operatic stages across Europe and even the entire world, and it still resonates with the golden voice of the diva, Maria Callas. Half of its repertoire is dedicated to Italian scores, and the other half to French, German, and Russian composers, as well as their theatre directors and orchestra conductors.

Robert Wilson and Deborah Warner are just some of the names that have boosted La Scala's international reputation, which is always on the lookout for emerging talent.

La Scala
Via Filodrammatici 2
20121 Milano

+39 02 7200 3744

www.teatroallascala.org/en

content.title: Maison Borella: a family home in the trendy Tortona neighbourhood

introduction.small: This quiet, charming residence is one of the few hotels on the Navigli canals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maison Borella: a family home in the trendy Tortona neighbourhood

paragraphs.text:
The popular Tortona district has become one of the favourite areas of the new Milanese bohemian bourgeoisie, and the trendiest fashion houses have all moved in

Near the antique market and the flower market, this hotel is an architectural gem of the 18th century. It melds the charm of the past with refined contemporary furnishings. You will feel deliciously wonderful in these soundproofed rooms that overlook the canal (Milan's navigli), some with even a small terrace. In fine weather, enjoy the pleasantly shaded courtyard.

For the business traveller, Maison Borella provides its customers with meeting rooms. And, just 200 metres away, a private house, former casa di righiera (typical Milanese old-railing house) can accommodate four persons for a family holiday or a seminar.

Maison Borella
Alzaia Naviglio Grande 8
20144 Milano

+39 02 5810 9114

https://www.hotelmaisonborella.com/

Rooms: from 144 EUR

content.title: Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II: a walk in the heart of Milan

introduction.small: Nicknamed 'the salon of Milan', this pedestrian gallery cultivates the art of Milanese living.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II: a walk in the heart of Milan

paragraphs.text:
It was built in 1867, six years after the reunification of Italy by Victor Emmanuel II of Savoy. Its dome is one of the first constructions made out of glass and iron in Europe, and its perilous building process cost the life of its architect.

It is considered by the Milanese to be the 'salon of Milan', connecting the Duomo to La Scala, and a place where all Milan meets or goes for a stroll. Lawyers and notaries get together there for their morning espressos; society ladies go there to enjoy their panettones in the afternoon. Like many places at one time in their history, the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II temporarily lost its splendour and was taken over by cheap curio shops.

But, now that is over, and it has rediscovered its Milanese spirit. The chic shops are back, including Prada, for whom this is a homecoming. It was here that Mario Prada founded his luggage shop in 1913.

Galleria Victor Emmanuel II
Piazza del Duomo
20123 Milano

+39 02 8845 5555

https://www.yesmilano.it/en/see-and-do/venues/galleria-vittorio-emanuele-ii

content.title: Novecento Museum, the Museum of the 20th century

introduction.small: Dedicated to the art of the 20th century, this museum is especially popular with artists and fashion designers who love its wealth of creativity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Novecento Museum, the Museum of the 20th century

paragraphs.text:
Devoted to the art movements of the 20th century, this extraordinary museum was designed by architects Italo Rota and Fabio Fornasari and built in 1936. It consists in two symmetrical palaces located on each side of the Via Guglielmo Marconi, leading to the Piazza Armando Diaz.

In the entrance, there is an immense painting by Eugenio de Chirico entitled The Fountain of Mysterious Baths. Then, as you go up the spiral ramp, you gradually climb through the years, up to our contemporary era. The art shifts from Divisionism and Futurism to 60s Arte Povera, for example.

In addition to some Modigliani and Kandinsky, you will find works by artists like Umberto Boccioni, Gino Severini, Mario Sironi and Fausto Melotti.

On the upper level, you cannot pass by the entire panoramic room dedicated to Lucio Fontana (1899-1968), the Italian artist of Argentinean origin who founded Spatialism, a movement inherent to Informal art.

Novecento Museum
Piazza Duomo 8
20123 Milano

+39 02 8844 4061

https://www.museodelnovecento.org/en/

content.title: Triennale Design Museum: the first museum dedicated to contemporary design

introduction.small: Milan is the capital of fashion… and of design too.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Triennale Design Museum: the first museum dedicated to contemporary design

paragraphs.text:
Every year in April, the city vibrates to the rhythm of the Salon del Mobile. This international event brings together all the major design labels like Cassini, Kartell, Alessi, Artemide as well as emerging designers like Daniele Bortotto and Giorgia Zanellato.

It was therefore logical in Milan that there would be a space dedicated to the art of furniture, which has had so much of an impact on the city. In 2007, the design museum opened on the third floor of the Milan Triennale. Thanks to a very rich curation, including exhibitions of various projects, drawings, photographs and models, film screenings, conferences and the possibility to consult of archival books and magazines on site, the museum reveals the past without being confined by it. One of its best exhibits tells the story of electric appliances, showing how they transformed themselves over the 20th century into what they are today. Absorbing and even exciting, by turns!

Triennale di Milano
Viale Emilio Alemagna 6
20121 Milano

+39 02 724 341

https://www.triennale.org/en/

content.title: The Santa Maria delle Grazie Church and the Leonardo da Vinci fresco

introduction.small: Beauty, mystery, and fragility: The Last Supper is one of the finest works of the great Renaissance genius.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Santa Maria delle Grazie Church and the Leonardo da Vinci fresco

paragraphs.text:
Milan considers Leonardo Da Vinci its native son. He lived here for 20 years and it is where he developed his engineering talents to their fullest. At the request of Lord Sforza, his patron, he painted The Last Supper on the walls of the refectory of the convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie.

The masterpiece has been in peril since its inception because, to accelerate the work, Leonardo devised a faster drying process. As a result, only 20 years after the fresco was completed it began deteriorating.

Since then, it has been a major headache: restorers continue to come up with methods to protect this monument listed as a UNESCO World Heritage since 1980. Some say that the fresco contains many mysteries and hidden puzzles devised by the Renaissance genius. Could John the Apostle have been a woman? How many biblical tales are reproduced on the fresco? Did Leonardo da Vinci want to paint Jesus and the apostles like mere mortal beings, far from the standards of his time? Try and left all preconceptions and see The Last Supper as its creator conceived it.

Santa Maria delle Grazie church
Piazza di Santa Maria delle Grazie
20123 Milano

+39 02 467 6111

https://www.yesmilano.it/en/see-and-do/venues/last-supper

content.title: The Unicredit Tower: ‘Mirror, mirror on the wall'

introduction.small: This glass tower reflects Milan and its revival.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Unicredit Tower: ‘Mirror, mirror on the wall'

paragraphs.text:
A city long overshadowed by its industrial greyness, Milan is finally taking its revenge. It has placed its architectural revival in the hands of people like Zaha Hadid and Araka Isozaki.

Built on a former railway yard near the Garibaldi train station in the new district of Puerto Nueva, the UniCredit Tower is the new pride of the Milanese. At a height of 230 metres, it is the tallest tower in Italy and the most connected to sustainable development. Sheathed in glass, the UniCredit bank headquarters was designed by the Argentinean architect, César Pelli. Its visual beauty and ecological features have earned it numerous prestigious awards.

With the sky reflected on its exterior panels, it absorbs solar energy, significantly reducing the lighting and heating costs of its 33 floors. The three-building complex houses offices, restaurants, and shops.

UniCredit tower
Piazza Gae Aulenti 3
20154 Milano

+39 02 8862 4385

https://www.yesmilano.it/en/see-and-do/venues/porta-nuova-and-corso-como

content.title: Via Monte Napoleone: the fashion district

introduction.small: With Prada, Armani, Versace, and Gucci, Milan is both the capital of Italian fashion and the showcase for fashion's most prestigious houses.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Via Monte Napoleone: the fashion district

paragraphs.text:
Italian elegance is not a myth. Just look at the stylishness of Via Monte Napoleone, which proves that chic is second nature to Italians.

Via Monte Napoleone, Via Della Spiga, Via Santa Andrea, Via Alessandro Manzoni and Corso Venezia constitute what the Milanese call the 'Golden Quadrilateral'. Armani, Dolce & Gabbana, Versace, Roberto Cavalli, Valentino, Pucci, Gucci... all the major Italian houses have shops here. They are true palaces of fashion and the constant reinvention of the art of living. A hymn to Milanese culture, the neighbourhood is regarded as paradise for all fashionistas. Yet, it never forgets about its past, and you will see museums elbowing high fashion workshops.

Visit the new Bottega Veneta home boutique. In a luxurious 18th-century residence, it features furniture for every room in the house. The ambience fits in perfectly with the original architecture of the residence, and is much enhanced by two magnificent frescoes, including one by Tiepolo.

https://www.yesmilano.it/en/see-and-do/venues/quadrilatero-della-moda-fashion-district

content.title: Trattoria Madonnina l'Osteria: the oldest trattoria in the city

introduction.small: People come here to immerse themselves in an authentic Milan and to mingle warmly with a clientele of regulars and artists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Trattoria Madonnina l'Osteria: the oldest trattoria in the city

paragraphs.text:
Located only a stone's throw from the Navigli, that canal district equally pleasant to visit by foot or by boat, along the quays, this trattoria claims to be the oldest in the city, and proves it with its old theatre posters, yellowed photos, a grandmother-style buffet, and chequered tablecloths.

Come at noon to enjoy simple and hearty dishes like the osso buco, the risotto, the ravioli al brasato (ravioli stuffed with braised beef) or a Milanese cutlet, all in a no-frills atmosphere. Diners range from locals (many of them having turned the place into their canteen) to business people looking for a break, as well as various idling students. A place that exudes authentic Milanese ambience like no other.

Trattoria Madonnina l'Osteria
Via Gentilino 6
20136 Milano

+39 02 8940 9089

https://www.facebook.com/lamadonninamilano

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: Carlo e Camilla in Segheria: the new Milanese cuisine

introduction.small: Located in a former mill, this restaurant epitomises new Milanese energy with a menu that reinterprets Italian cuisine by adding a modern twist.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Carlo e Camilla in Segheria: the new Milanese cuisine

paragraphs.text:
At first, the decor can be a little disconcerting. It seems more fitting for an art display than a dining room. Imagine a vast workshop with crude walls and floors, and in the centre, four long tables in the form of a cross. You are in one of the most popular venues in Milan.

Design-wise, the lighting, Cappellini chairs selected by curator Tanja Solci. The mismatched plates (with over a hundred different references) come from the collections of Richard Ginori.

Food-wise, chef Luca Pedata executes excellent cuisine, reinterpreting Italian traditions with modernity and a lightness of touch. Everything is fresh, seasonal, and local, and the menu changes every two months. You may be in luck and try the grilled pigeon in artichokes, beetroot, grilled lentils and cherries for instance.

It is best to book ahead. Though the restaurant is a 'table d'hôte', an intimate dinner for two is also possible.

Carlo e Camilla in Segheria
Via Giuseppe Meda 24
20136 Milano

+39 02 837 3963

https://www.carloecamillainsegheria.it/en/

Menu: around 45 EUR

content.title: Bulgari Hotel: a lush palace next to La Scala

introduction.small: As a place to relax and breathe in deeply, nothing beats a break in the extraordinary garden of this palace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bulgari Hotel: a lush palace next to La Scala

paragraphs.text:
Close to the must-see Pinacoteco di Brera, just behind an austere facade that blocks out the urban bustle lies the most beautiful, peaceful palace hotel in Milan. Could it be otherwise when one bears the name of Bulgari?

Emerald is this Italian jeweller's favourite stone. Its green is embodied in a garden of 4000 square metres, which is an extension of the Botanical Garden. The hotel is literally under the spell of this vegetal tranquillity, whose peacefulness extends even into the interior areas.

Architect Antonio Citterio has designed them to be harmonious, refined, pure, and restful, while renovating the 18th-century building. Light oak, teak, black Zimbabwean granite fireplace, cream-coloured linen… the materials reflect calm the essence of luxury. Reinvigorate yourself with a spa treatment and a dip in the pure-gold-tiled swimming pool. After all, everyone knows about gold's regenerative powers...

Bulgari Hotel
Via Privata Fratelli Gabba 7b
20121 Milano

+39 02 805 8051

https://www.bulgarihotels.com/en_US/milan

Rooms: from 663 EUR

content.title: 10 Corso Como: at the crossroads of fashion and design

introduction.small: Carla Sozzani's assured taste has made this concept shop the ultimate showcase for trends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 10 Corso Como: at the crossroads of fashion and design

paragraphs.text:
At the back of the courtyard past an overgrown garden, you climb up the stairs to the left, which lead to the gallery and bookshop.

The art, photography, architecture, and fashion are always of the moment, and it is rare to leave empty-handed. The gallery is curated according to whatever its founder, Carla Sozzani, feels is right for the moment.

On the ground floor is a vast hangar-sized boutique that has the feel of a flea market or consignment shop. You can find anything, from vintage Paco Rabanne and sculptural Azzedine Alaïa dresses, to clothing from current designers like Mary Katzantrou and Jeremy Scott. And, of course, beautiful accessories. In terms of food, you can get a bite to eat or have a working lunch. Sozzani has also recently added a mini hotel to the concept store: it has three rooms, which have the look and feel of real guest bedrooms.

10 Corso Como
Corso Como 10
20154 Milano

+39 02 2900 2674 (shop) / +39 02 653 531 (gallery)

www.10corsocomo.com

content.title: Bice: a lighter take on Milanese cuisine

introduction.small: The grand daughters of the founder of this typical trattoria perpetuate the tradition and reputation of this very good restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bice: a lighter take on Milanese cuisine

paragraphs.text:
It is impossible not to order a risotto alla Milanese-saffron risotto-in which butter and Parmesan cheese are added to make it creamy. It is so rich here that it is not an appetiser but a main course. It also comes in a lighter version, as the Ruggeri sisters have made the menu heavy on light, vegetarian cuisine to suit the slender silhouettes of Via Monte Napoleone. All of the 'Golden Quadrilateral' comes to this traditional trattoria, which also does "light" versions of grilled shrimp in mint and curry served with rice pilaf for lunch and dinner. However, should you crave some more delights, try the homemade pasta with fresh tomatoes, basil pesto, fish roe cream, cep mushrooms and, when season is right, some in-demand Alba truffle.

For dessert, even just once, try the Gianduja ice cream.

Bice Milano
Via Borgospesso 12
20121 Milano

+39 02 7600 2572

https://www.bicemilano.it

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: Madama Hostel Bistro: stay in alternative Milan

introduction.small: Make the best of this warm and welcoming place amidst a building… of unusual heritage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Madama Hostel Bistro: stay in alternative Milan

paragraphs.text:
Italians do not lack for humour. Proof? This hostel is housed in a former police station. No trace of its previous existence remains however.

Everything is based on a friendly and communal experience with a shared kitchen, billiard room, and, of course, dormitories that sleep up to six people. Some of them are reserved for women, while others are mixed. Couples can book a private room with a double bed. All furnishings are made from recycled materials, predominantly wood. More than a mere hostel, the establishment houses a gallery dedicated to street art, with about fifteen works signed by international names, spread around various rooms.

A true living space, Madama offers yoga classes, bicycles, and, if necessary, babysitters. Breakfast is included, and, of course, so is Wi-Fi.

Madama Hostel Bistrot
Via Benaco 1
20139 Milano

+39 02 3672 7370

https://madamahostel.com/en/

Shared rooms: from 31 EUR; private rooms: from 85 EUR

content.title: E.c.ho. spells ‘ecological'

introduction.small: A 100% green hotel for business travellers and lovers of fashion and design.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: E.c.ho. spells ‘ecological'

paragraphs.text:
During the week, dark suits come and go in E.c.ho's lobby (the acronym stands for Ecological Contempory Hotel). On weekends, however, the hotel comes alive with patrons sporting more relaxed wear. Whether you come to Milan for business or pleasure, this hotel is prized choice for its strategic location, as it is close to the central train station and five minutes from the Duomo. It is favoured just as much for its philosophy, attuned to sustainable development issues.

Here, nothing is wasted, and everything is recycled. Electricity is supplied by solar panels, wastewater is recycled, and even the contemporary and refined decor favours recycled materials.

As for the restaurant, it serves seasonal menus showcasing organic vegetables from a nearby garden. Long before the 2015 World Expo, which advocated 'energy for life', the hotel committed itself to sustainable development. Today, its message is still very loud and clear.

E.c.ho. Hotel
Viale Andrea Doria 4
20124 Milano

+39 02 678 91

https://www.starhotels.com/en/our-hotels/echo-milan/

Rooms: from 110 EUR

content.title: LaFavia Four Rooms: a B&B that is just like home

introduction.small: Four rooms, a porch… and a roof garden.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: LaFavia Four Rooms: a B&B that is just like home

paragraphs.text:
Before settling in Milan, Fabio and Marco first travelled around the world. From this trip, they brought back objects, paintings, and more importantly, a very definite notion of hospitality. They have put this into practice in this charming guesthouse, in which the charm of history perfectly matches modern comfort.

The four bedrooms are carpeted with English wallpaper, furnished with 1970s lamps, and decorated with Oriental tapestries, 1950s furniture, and Indian rugs. Everything has been put together with taste and finesse, and without one false note.

As soon as you set down your luggage, you are suffused with a strange feeling of having come home after a long trip. You find yourself among familiar objects. All this is compounded by attentiveness, quality, and generosity, especially the breakfasts, which are a delight to take on the flowered terrace before heading out to enjoy the many riches of Milan's heritage and other surrounding wonders.

LaFavia Four Rooms
Via Carlo Farini 4
20154 Milano

+39 0347 784 2212

lafavia4rooms.com/?lang=en

Rooms: from 90 EUR

content.title: The Duomo: Milan would not be Milan without its cathedral

introduction.small: Looking as if it is made of lace, the Duomo is breath-taking in its beauty. Milan's cathedral is at the epicentre of the city's cultural and economic life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Duomo: Milan would not be Milan without its cathedral

paragraphs.text:
Once upon a time, in the 14th century, the Milanese lord, Gian Galeazza Visconti, wanted to build a cathedral that reflected his omnipotence. He chose to build it out of the most precious marble, from Candoglia in Piedmont.

Unfortunately, this marble is as fragile as it is rare. Exposed to wind, sun, rain, even just air, it oxidises and deteriorates, and nothing can stop this process. Though it was scarcely completed, the cathedral was already fated for destruction. Pieces must be changed regularly. That is why, over the centuries, its style has evolved. It has gone from neo-Gothic to Gothic with a slight Baroque influence.

Its 136 spires and 3,500 statues have earned it its affectionate nickname, 'the marble hedgehog'. Its interior is just as beautiful, thanks to the crucifix by Leonardo da Vinci.

Do not miss the Duomo's terraces, as they bring out the promise of an unusual stroll between artistic details and a panoramic view of Milan. Book your tickets online and you will benefit from priority-access tickets, which should save you a few hours of waiting in line.

The Duomo
Piazza del Duomo
20122 Milano

+39 02 7202 3375

https://www.duomomilano.it/en/

content.title: (Petit): a cosy bistro that's an alternative to high-design restaurants

introduction.small: Inspired by the spirit of Parisian bistros, this restaurant offers the classics of Italian cooking.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: (Petit): a cosy bistro that's an alternative to high-design restaurants

paragraphs.text:
(Petit) is run by Simona Miele and Luca Guelfi, who own several restaurants in Italy and the Caribbean. (Petit) also has an older brother-(Petit) in Miami. Located in the Porta Nuova neighbourhood, (Petit) breaks the code of alpine restaurants with its decor. The tables and chairs are of Parisian inspiration, while the mirrors and pale colours are Scandinavian. At night, the room is illuminated by more than a hundred chandeliers, candles, and candelabras, which give the space a cosy and romantic atmosphere. The Milanese love it... The other part of the restaurant houses a grocery and a real Italian mamma-style trattoria. The sausages are hung on the wall, the hams are enthroned beside the slicing machine, and at your table, the menu offers a variety of homemade dishes that satisfy all appetites. Try, among others, the fresh salmon carpaccio and, for dessert, the tiramisu, a speciality of nearby Piedmont. The octopus salad with potatoes, tomatoes and olives, and the tuna steak served with pistachios and mashed Jerusalem artichoke nicely complement the menu.

(Petit) Milano
Via Amerigo Vespucci 5
20124 Milano

+39 02 8969 0870

https://www.petitbistrogroup.com/milano

Menu: around 35 EUR

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Milan
content.introduction: Milan has a humid continental climate with hot summers, no real dry season, and significant rainfall throughout the year. Winters are cold, raw and relatively snowy. In both the autumn and winter, the city and its environs can often be shrouded in a thick layer of fog. And yet, Milan enjoys a great deal of sunshine (6 to 9 hours a day) between April and September and thus attracts a large influx of tourists every summer!

airports.title: Milan International Airports
airports.description:
Milan Malpensa International Airport

The Milan Malpensa International Airport is located about 50 kilometres (31 miles) northwest of the city centre.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1 Malpensa West (Air France)
    • Terminal 2 Malpensa North

Getting from the airport to Milan and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the A8 from Milan.
    • Drop-off (P3), long-term (P1), Business (P2), Holiday (P4), and Easy (P5) parking facilities available at the airport. For short-term parking, the price is EUR 4 per hour, EUR 29 per day.
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals halls of Terminal 1.
  • By shuttle bus
    • Several bus companies offer shuttle bus services between the airport and Milano Centrale train station, with departures every 10 minutes from 5:05 a.m. to 12:10 a.m. and a travel time of about 50 minutes. A one-way ticket costs about EUR 8.
  • By rail
    • Malpensa Express trains (https://www.malpensaexpress.it/en/) leave from the underground level at Terminal 1, connecting the airport with Milano Cadorna station every half-hour. Trains operate from 5:20 a.m. to 12:20 a.m. every day, with a travel time of about one hour to Cadorna, and the one-way fare is EUR 13.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside each terminal. The fixed fare to any address within the city area is EUR 95 (for a maximum of four passengers with luggage).
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available at the airport.
  • Telephone: +39 (0)2 23 23 23
  • Website: https://www.milanomalpensa-airport.com/en/

 

Milan Linate International Airport

The Milan Linate International Airport is located about 7 kilometres (4 miles) from the city centre.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Milan and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible from the north via the A4 and the A51, from the west via Viale Forlanini, and from the east via the A35-BreBeMi.
    • P1 (short-stay) and P2 (short- and long-stay) parking facilities available. EUR 4 per hour, EUR 34 per day.
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall.
  • By bus
    • Several bus lines connect the airport to the city centre and central station. EUR 1.5 to 3 for a one-way ticket. One bus every 20 to 30 minutes.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks just outside the arrivals hall, at exit 5. The fare to central Milan starts at about EUR 20.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available at the airport.
  • Telephone: +39 (0)2 23 23 23
  • Website: https://www.milanolinate-airport.com/en/

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Milan
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Milan each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 6: Epiphany (Feast of Befana) (national holiday)
events.description: For all Italians, the 6<sup>th</sup> of January is the day when the benevolent white witch Befana, who predates Santa Claus in Italy, arrives on her broomstick with presents and candy for all children who have been good during the year, or a lump of coal if they have been bad!

events.title: January 6: Parade of the Magi (Corteo dei Re Magi) (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also on Epiphany, a long procession, led by three men dressed up as the Magi and including a tableau vivant of the Nativity, makes its ways through the streets of Milan, from the Duomo to Sant'Eustorgio basilica, where a public ceremony is held.

events.title: Week leading to Easter: Holy Week (Settimana Santa) (national holiday)
events.description: Religious processions and other events fill the streets of Milan during the week leading up to Easter and special services are held in churches throughout the city, with particularly elaborate liturgical ceremonies at Milan's Duomo, the world's third-largest cathedral, dedicated to Saint Mary of the Nativity.

events.title: April 25: Liberation Day (Festa della Liberazione) (national holiday)
events.description: Each year, this holiday commemorates the end of World War II in Italy. It is marked by parades, marching bands, speeches, and fireworks.

events.title: March/April: Lunedì dell'Angelo (local event)
events.description: This Franciscan flower market, which has been held on Pasquetta (Easter Monday) for more than 400 years, celebrates the beginning of spring. Stalls take over Piazza Sant'Angelo and the streets between Piazza di Repubblica and Brera selling not only flowers, but also handicrafts, books and food items.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (Festa del Lavoro) (national holiday)
events.description: On Labour Day, which is a holiday in Italy, many artistic associations organise events in the historic centre of the city, featuring shows, workshops, street theatre, and a host of other events.

events.title: June 2: Republic Day (Festa della Repubblica) (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday commemorates the national referendum voted on this day in 1946, when the Italian people chose a republic instead of a monarchy. In Milan, as in the rest of Italy, celebrations include official ceremonies, a military parade, fireworks, concerts and street parties.

events.title: August 15:Assumption (Assunzione della Beata Vergine Maria) (national)
events.description: This holiday is dedicated to the worship of the Virgin Mary. Masses and processions are held in her honour in churches and streets of the historic centre.

events.title: November 1: All Souls Day (Ognissanti) (national)
events.description: All Saints Day is celebrated throughout Italy with various religious events, especially in the churches of Milan.

events.title: November 4: Day of Italian Unification (Giorno dell'Unità Nazionale) (national)
events.description: On this day of official commemorations, Italy celebrates both its unification by the Kings of the House of Savoy and the end of the First World War. This national Armed Forces Day is marked by many military parades.

events.title: December 7: Festa di Sant'Ambrogio (local event)
events.description: The feast day of Milan's patron saint is celebrated with a street market selling regional foods, especially sweets, as well as seasonal handicrafts and antiques on the grounds of the Castello Sforzesco. A special mass is held at the Sant'Ambrogio basilica.

events.title: December 26: Day of Saint Stephen (Santo Stefano) (national)
events.description: This day has been a holiday in Italy since 1947 and celebrates the birth of St Stephen, the first martyr of Christianity. Traditionally, it is a day dedicated to the family, with a large festive meal.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Italy
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Italy for less than three months. If you plan to stay for more than 90 days, you will need to obtain a long-stay visa.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Milan and Italy, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ website. View information for travellers to Italy:

https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/italy/#

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping

In Milan like everywhere in Italy, a service charge (servizio) is usually included in the bill at restaurants. If the service is exceptional, you can certainly leave a few extra euros. Some restaurants also apply a cover charge (pane e coperto, literally "bread and cutlery"), which is not considered as a gratuity. You should therefore make sure beforehand that tip and cover charge are included in the bill!
